custom_item_1.description: Fortigate - Review users with admin privileges
custom_item_1.info:
A periodic review of users with administrative privileges ensures that organizational changes are reflected in the device configuration.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_2.description: Fortigate - Review the NTP server configuration
custom_item_2.info:
Ensuring that approved NTP servers are used allows for accurate log/audit file correlation.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_3.info: Ensuring that approved NTP servers are used allows for accurate log/audit file correlation - '*.ntp.org'

custom_item_4.description: Fortigate - Admin password policy is enabled

custom_item_5.info: Require the new administrative password to differ from the old password by at least four characters. Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_6.info: Ensure that the administrator password length is at least 8 (MAX 32). Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_7.info: Password must contain at least one lowercase letter. Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_8.info: Password must contain at least one uppercase letter. Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_9.info: Password must contain at least one non-alphanumeric character. Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_10.description: Fortigate - Password Complexity - at least 1 char
custom_item_10.info: Password must contain at least one character. Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_11.info: Require that passwords expire. Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_12.info: Ensure that the administrator password has an expiry date of at most 30 days. Enforcing strong password policies reduces the chance that a password will be compromised.

custom_item_13.info: Grayware programs are unsolicited software programs installed on computers, often without the user's consent or knowledge. Grayware programs are generally considered an annoyance, but they can also cause system performance problems or be used for malicious purposes.
custom_item_13.solution:
Use this command to enable grayware detection as part of antivirus scanning.

config antivirus settings
set grayware enable
end

custom_item_14.info: Synchronize log messages with an external log server to have a backup of log messages for analysis if the FortiGate unit is compromised.

custom_item_15.info: Synchronize log messages with an external log server to have a backup of log messages for analysis if the FortiGate unit is compromised.

custom_item_19.info: Synchronize log messages with an external log server to have a backup of log messages for analysis if the FortiGate unit is compromised.

custom_item_20.description: Fortigate - Encrypt logs sent to FortiAnalyzer/FortiManager
custom_item_20.info: To keep information in log messages sent to FortiAnalyzer private, go to Log & Report > Log Settings and when you configure Remote Logging to FortiAnalyzer/FortiManager select Encrypt log transmission.
custom_item_20.solution:
From the CLI:

config log {fortianalyzer | fortianalyzer2 | fortianalyzer3} setting
    set enc-algorithm high
end

custom_item_21.info: Synchronize local log messages with an external log server to have a backup of log messages for analysis if the external unit is compromised.
custom_item_21.solution:
Use this command to configure log settings for logging to the local disk. Disk logging is only
available for FortiGate units with an internal hard disk. You can also use this command to
configure the FortiGate unit to upload current log files to an FTP server every time the log files
are rolled.

config log disk setting
 set status enable
end

custom_item_22.info: The FortiGate unit logs all messages at and above the logging severity level you select. Record as many log messages as you can without affecting FortiGate performance. More log messages means more visibility into what's happening with the system.
custom_item_22.solution:
Use this command to configure log level settings.

config log disk filter
 set severity information
end

custom_item_23.info: The FortiGate unit logs all messages at and above the logging severity level you select. Record as many log messages as you can without affecting FortiGate performance. More log messages means more visibility into what's happening with the system.
custom_item_23.solution:
Use this command to configure log level settings.

end

custom_item_24.solution:

custom_item_30.info: Log system activity messages, HA activity messages, CPU and memory usage, VIP realserver health monitoring, and AMC interface bypass mode messages. Record as many log messages as you can without affecting FortiGate performance. More log messages means more visibility into what's happening with the system.
custom_item_30.solution:
Use this command to Log system events.

config log eventfilter
 set system enable
end

custom_item_31.info: Log user authentication messages. Record as many log messages as you can without affecting FortiGate performance. More log messages means more visibility into what's happening with the system.
custom_item_31.solution:
Use this command to Log user authentication messages.

config log eventfilter
 set user enable
end

custom_item_32.info: Log IPSec negotiation messages, SSL user authentication, administration and session messages. Record as many log messages as you can without affecting FortiGate performance. More log messages means more visibility into what's happening with the system.
custom_item_32.solution:
Use this command to Log VPN events.

config log eventfilter
 set vpn enable
end

custom_item_33.info: Log WAN optimization messages. Record as many log messages as you can without affecting FortiGate performance. More log messages means more visibility into what's happening with the system.
custom_item_33.solution:
Use this command to log WAN optimization messages.

config log eventfilter
 set wan-opt enable
end

custom_item_34.info: Log wireless activity. Record as many log messages as you can without affecting FortiGate performance. More log messages means more visibility into what's happening with the system.
custom_item_34.solution:
Use this command to log Wireless-activity events.

config log eventfilter
 set wireless-activity enable
end

custom_item_36.info: Alert email provides an efficient and direct method of notifying an administrator of events. By configuring alert messages, you can define the threshold when a problem becomes critical and needs attention. When this threshold is reached, the FortiGate unit will send an email to one or more individuals notifying them of the issue.
custom_item_36.solution:
Use this command to set an alertmail admin email address.

config alertemail setting
 set mailto1end

custom_item_38.info: FortiManager - Auto backup is configured. Automatically backing up the configuration allows for easy restoration of configuration settings. It also allows for change comparison.
custom_item_38.solution:
Use this command to configure auto backup via 'FortiManager'.

config system central-management
 set mode backup
end

custom_item_39.description: Fortigate - Review the patch update method
custom_item_39.info:
Review the patch update method and current version. Ensuring timely updates are applied helps to remediate vulnerabilities or technical issues in the appliance.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_40.description: Fortigate - Review and disable unused interfaces
custom_item_40.info:
Review and disable unused interfaces. Disabling unused interfaces reduces the attack surface of the device.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_40.solution:
If any of the interfaces on the FortiGate unit are not being used, disable traffic on that interface. This avoids someone plugging in network cables and potentially causing network bypass or loop issues.

To disable an interface - web-based manager
1 Go to System > Network > Interface.
2 Select the interface from the list and select Edit.
3 For Administrative Access, select Down.
4 Select OK.

To disable an interface - CLI

config system interface
 editset status down
end

custom_item_41.description: Fortigate - Does not use self-signed certificate - 'admin'
custom_item_41.info: The web interface does not use the system self-signed certificate. A certificate from a trusted CA allows for secure identification of the appliance to clients.
custom_item_41.solution: From the web based manager go to System->Certificates->Import.

custom_item_42.description: Fortigate - Does not use self-signed certificate - 'user'
custom_item_42.info: The web interface does not use the system self-signed certificate. A certificate from a trusted CA allows for secure identification of the appliance to clients.
custom_item_42.solution: From the web based manager go to System->Certificates->Import.

custom_item_43.description: Fortigate - HTTPS/SSH admin access strong ciphers
custom_item_43.info: Only allow strong ciphers (AES, 3DES) and digest (SHA1) for HTTPS/SSH admin access.
custom_item_43.solution:
Issue the following command to enable strong-crypto.

config system global
 set strong-crypto enable
end

custom_item_44.description: Fortigate - Ensure default admin usernames are not used
custom_item_44.info: Ensure the default admin username is not used. The default super_admin administrator account, admin, is a well known administrator name so if this account is available it could be easier for attackers to access the FortiGate unit because they know they can log in with this name, only having to determine the password. You can improve security by changing this name to one more difficult for an attacker to guess.
custom_item_44.solution:
To do this, create a new administrator account with the super_admin admin profile and log in as that administrator. Then go to System > Admin > Administrators and Edit the admin administrator and change the Administrator name.
Once the account has been renamed you could delete the super_admin account that you just added. Consider also only using the super-admin account for adding or changing administrators. The less this account is used to less likely that it could be compromised. You could also store the account name and password for this account in a secure location in case for some reason the account name or password is forgotten.

custom_item_45.info: Disable SSHv1 admin access. SSHv2 offers better security in the form of enhanced encryption, MAC and certificates.
custom_item_45.solution:
Issue the following command to disable SSHv1 admin access.

config system global
 set admin-ssh-v1 disable
end

custom_item_46.description: Fortigate - SSH login grace time <= 30 seconds
custom_item_46.info: SSH login grace time <= 30 seconds. When logging into the console using SSH, the default time of inactivity to successfully log into the FortiGate unit is 120 seconds (2 minutes). You can configure the time to be shorter which in turn will provide a less desirable target for attackers.
custom_item_46.solution:
Issue the following command to configure SSH login grace time.

config system global
 set admin-ssh-grace-timeend

custom_item_47.info: Administrator password lockout threshold - 1. Reduce the number of unsuccessful login attempts before they are locked out for a set amount of time. Enforcing this threshold will provide a less desirable target for attackers.
custom_item_47.solution:
Issue the following command to configure the admin-lockout-threshold.

config system global
 set admin-lockout-thresholdend

custom_item_48.info: Admin password lockout >= 300 seconds. Enforcing a longer wait time for subsequent login attempts will provide for a less desirable target for attackers.
custom_item_48.solution:
Issue the following command to configure the admin-lockout-duration.

config system global
 set admin-lockout-durationend

custom_item_49.info: Users are logged out after 5 minutes of inactivity or less - global. Set a timeout to avoid the possibility of an administrator walking away from the management computer and leaving it exposed to unauthorized personnel.
custom_item_49.solution:
Issue the following command to configure the admintimeout.

config system global
 set admintimeoutend

custom_item_51.info: Users are logged out after 5 minutes of inactivity or less - console.
custom_item_51.solution:
Issue the following command to configure the admin-console-timeout.

config system global
 set admin-console-timeoutend

custom_item_52.info: Users are logged out after 5 minutes of inactivity or less - console.
custom_item_52.solution:
Issue the following command to configure the admin-console-timeout.

config system global
 set admin-console-timeoutend

custom_item_53.description: Fortigate - Close port TCP 113 on external interface
custom_item_53.info: You can use the config system interface command to disable unused protocols that attackers may attempt to use to gather information about a FortiGate unit. Many of these protocols are disabled by default. Using the config system interface command you can see the current configuration of each of these options for the selected interface and then choose to disable them if required.
custom_item_53.solution:
To disable the port on the wan1 interface, use the following CLI command:

config system interface
 edit wan1
  set ident-accept disable
end

custom_item_54.description: Fortigate - Use non default admin access ports - 'HTTPS'
custom_item_54.info: Defense in depth - Use non-default administrative access ports - HTTPS.
custom_item_54.solution:
Issue the following command to change the port used for HTTPS:

config system global
 set admin-sportend

custom_item_55.description: Fortigate - Use non default admin access ports - 'SSH'
custom_item_55.info: Defense in depth - Use non-default administrative access ports - SSH.
custom_item_55.solution:
Issue the following command to change the port used for SSH:

config system global
 set admin-ssh-portend

custom_item_56.description: Fortigate - VPN SSL cipher suite > than 128 bits
custom_item_56.info: Ensure VPN SSL settings use a cipher suite that is greater than 128 bits.
custom_item_56.solution:
Issue the following command to use a cipher suite that is greater than 128 bits for VPN SSL:

config vpn ssl settings
 set algorithm high
end

custom_item_57.info: HTTP is insecure by nature as it sends all traffic across the wire in clear text.
custom_item_57.solution:
Use the following command to specific access protocols for a given interface:

config system interface
 editset allowaccessend

custom_item_58.info: Telnet is insecure by nature as it sends all traffic across the wire in clear text.
custom_item_58.solution:
Use the following command to specific access protocols for a given interface:

config system interface
 editset allowaccessend

custom_item_59.info: The pre-login banner should be reviewed to ensure it complies with organizational standards.
custom_item_59.solution:
Use the following command to enable use of the pre-login banner:

config system global
 set pre-login-banner enable
end

custom_item_60.info: The post login banner should be reviewed to ensure it complies with organizational standards.
custom_item_60.solution:
Use the following command to enable use of the post-login banner:

config system global
 set post-login-banner enable
end

custom_item_61.info: The DNS server IP address should be reviewed. A DNS server may return malicious IP addresses in response to requests for domains that are normally good. This provides an avenue to leak information about the appliance or to download untrusted content.
custom_item_61.solution:
Use the following command to configure the primary DNS server address:

config system dns
 set primaryend

custom_item_62.info: The DNS server IP address should be reviewed. A DNS server may return malicious IP addresses in response to requests for domains that are normally good. This provides an avenue to leak information about the appliance or to download untrusted content.
custom_item_62.solution:
Use the following command to configure the primary DNS server address:

config system dns
 set secondaryend

custom_item_63.info:
AAA - TACACS+ - ensure TACACS+ server is trusted - review configuration.

custom_item_66.info:
Note - this reports on the trusted hosts for the default user 'admin'. You can choose to copy this check and replace the username 'admin' with other user names. Setting trusted hosts for an administrator limits what computer/location an administrator can log into the FortiGate unit from. When you identify a trusted host, the FortiGate unit will only accept the administrator's login from the configured IP address of the trusted host. Any attempt to log in with the same credentials from any other IP address will be dropped.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_66.solution:
To add a trusted host for an administrative user, use the following command:

config system admin
 editset {trusthost1 | trusthost2 | trusthost3 | trusthost4
| trusthost5 | trusthost6 | trusthost7 | trusthost8
| trusthost9 | trusthost10}end

custom_item_67.info: Enables support for remote access by Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).
custom_item_67.solution:
To enable snmp, use the following command:

config system snmp sysinfo
 set status enable
end

custom_item_69.info: Ensure SNMP does not use an easy to guess or default community string - 'public'.
custom_item_69.solution:
To set the SNMP community string use the following command:

config system snmp community
 editset nameend

custom_item_70.info: Ensure SNMP does not use an easy to guess or default community string - 'private'.
custom_item_70.solution:
To set the SNMP community string use the following command:

config system snmp community
 editset nameend

custom_item_72.description: Fortigate - SNMP v3 uses SHA instead of MD5
custom_item_72.info: SNMP v3 uses SHA instead of MD5
custom_item_72.solution:
To set the SNMP MD type use the following command:

config system snmp user
  set auth-proto sha
end

custom_item_73.description: Fortigate - SNMP v3 users have passwords

custom_item_74.description: Fortigate - SNMP v3 users have passwords

custom_item_75.description: Fortigate - SNMP v3 uses AES instead of DES

custom_item_76.description: Fortigate - SNMP v3 uses AES instead of DES
custom_item_76.info: SNMP v3 uses AES instead of DES
custom_item_76.solution:
To configure SNMP to use AES, use the following command:

config system snmp user
  set priv-proto aes
end

custom_item_77.description: Fortigate - Enable logs of failed connection attempts
custom_item_77.info: Enable or disable logging of failed connection attempts to the FortiGate unit that use TCP/IP ports other than the TCP/IP ports configured for management access (443 for https, 22 for ssh, 23 for telnet, and 80 for HTTP by default).
custom_item_77.solution:
To enable logging, use the following command:

config log setting
  set local-in-deny-unicast enable
  set local-in-deny-broadcast enable
end

custom_item_78.description: Fortigate - RADIUS, LDAP, or TACACS+ response wait period
custom_item_78.info: The number of seconds that the FortiGate unit waits for responses from remote RADIUS, LDAP, or TACACS+ authentication servers. The range is 0 to 300 seconds, 0 means no timeout. To improve security keep the remote authentication timeout at the default value of 5 seconds. However, if a RADIUS request needs to traverse multiple hops or several RADIUS requests are made, the default timeout of 5 seconds may not be long enough to receive a response.
custom_item_78.solution:
To set the remote auth timeout, use the following command:

config system global
  set remoteauthtimeout 5
end

custom_item_79.info: Enabling this option may help resolve issues with a problematic server, but it can make the FortiGate unit more vulnerable to denial of service attacks. In most cases you should leave resetsessionless-tcp disabled.
custom_item_79.solution:
To set the reset-sessionless-tcp to disabled, use the following command:

config system global
  set reset-sessionless-tcp disable
end

custom_item_80.info: Ensuring licenses are valid and timely updates are applied helps to remediate vulnerabilities or technical issues in the appliance.
custom_item_80.solution: Verify the status of the FortiGuard services on the FortiGate unit. You can view the status of FortiGuard services from the License Information dashboard widget or from the System > Config > FortiGuard page. Renew any expired licenses.

custom_item_82.info: Ensuring licenses are valid and timely updates are applied helps to remediate vulnerabilities or technical issues in the appliance.
custom_item_82.solution: Verify the status of the FortiGuard services on the FortiGate unit. You can view the status of FortiGuard services from the License Information dashboard widget or from the System > Config > FortiGuard page. Renew any expired licenses.

custom_item_83.info: Ensuring licenses are valid and timely updates are applied helps to remediate vulnerabilities or technical issues in the appliance.
custom_item_83.solution: Verify the status of the FortiGuard services on the FortiGate unit. You can view the status of FortiGuard services from the License Information dashboard widget or from the System > Config > FortiGuard page. Renew any expired licenses.

custom_item_84.info: The FortiGate system memory has a limited capacity and displays only the most recent log entries. Traffic logs are not stored in the memory buffer, due to the high volume of traffic information. After all available memory is used, by default, the FortiGate unit begins to overwrite the oldest log messages. All log entries are deleted when the FortiGate unit restarts.
custom_item_84.solution:
To set the full-final-warning-threshold, use the following command:

config log memory global-setting
  set full-final-warning-threshold 95
end

custom_item_85.info: The FortiGate system memory has a limited capacity and displays only the most recent log entries. Traffic logs are not stored in the memory buffer, due to the high volume of traffic information. After all available memory is used, by default, the FortiGate unit begins to overwrite the oldest log messages. All log entries are deleted when the FortiGate unit restarts.
custom_item_85.solution:
To set the full-final-warning-threshold, use the following command:

config log memory global-setting
  set full-first-warning-threshold 75
end

custom_item_86.info: The FortiGate system memory has a limited capacity and displays only the most recent log entries. Traffic logs are not stored in the memory buffer, due to the high volume of traffic information. After all available memory is used, by default, the FortiGate unit begins to overwrite the oldest log messages. All log entries are deleted when the FortiGate unit restarts.
custom_item_86.solution:
To set the full-final-warning-threshold, use the following command:

config log memory global-setting
  set full-second-warning-threshold 90
end

custom_item_87.info: Use the extended database for IPS definitions.
custom_item_87.solution:
To set the IPS database to extended, use the following command:

config ips global
  set database extended
end

custom_item_88.info: SCP is disabled by default. Enabling SCP allows downloading the configuration file from the FortiGate as an alternative method of backing up the configuration file
custom_item_88.solution:
To enable SCP:

config system global
    set admin-scp enable
end

custom_item_89.info: If USB installation is enabled, an attacker with physical access to a FortiGate could load a new configuration or firmware on the FortiGate using the USB port.
custom_item_89.solution:
You can disable USB installation by entering the following from the CLI:

config system auto-install
    set auto-install-config disable
    set auto-install-image disable
end

custom_item_90.info: If USB installation is enabled, an attacker with physical access to a FortiGate could load a new configuration or firmware on the FortiGate using the USB port.
custom_item_90.solution:
You can disable USB installation by entering the following from the CLI:

config system auto-install
    set auto-install-config disable
    set auto-install-image disable
end

custom_item_91.description: Fortigate - Send malware statistics to FortiGuard 'Disabled'
custom_item_91.info: By default FortiOS periodically sends encrypted malware statistics to FortiGuard. The malware statistics record Antivirus, IPS, or Application Control events. This data is used to improved FortiGuard services. The malware statistics that FortiOS sends do not include any personal or sensitive customer data. The information is not shared with any external parties and is used in accordance with Fortinet's Privacy Policy.
custom_item_91.solution:
To disable sending malware statistics to FortiGuard:

config system global
    set fds-statistics disable
end
